reviews.text: We four went to el Born on a day when there were a lot of people, just seeking a pleasant way to spend some time. It was pleasant and full of local, and tourist centered shops.
Enjoyed it here, much quieter than the Ramblas etc...looked like there were plenty of restaurants and shops here too. The main church was lovely...we visited here on a walking tour .

This area id part of old Barcelona, beside Barri Gotic and down towards the beach. It's full of little lanes, interesting churches, little plazas nad great bars and restaurants. It's really worth just getting lost down here nad just having a wander around. There are lots of interesting little shops and boutiques, selling unque and intersing things.
This area is more modern and refined than El Born & Barri Gotic.  It's less touristy than the main Rambla, so the food is less mass marketed.

Beautiful old quarter with plenty of bars and small shops. Historic site of ancient excavations well presented. Don’t miss tapas bar Sagardi and Santa Maria del Mar. The small streets can seem frightening so would prefer to walk on one if the guided tours. Out guide showed us wonderful Graffiti.

Head for the El Born area in La Ribera: not over spoiled by mass tourism and you'll find a lot to enjoy: Basilica de Santa Maria del Mar, the Picasso Museum and El Born Museum. The plaza linking the Basilica and El Born Museum is pleasant and bounded with lots of choice for food and drink. Good to sit and eat and watch life.

I used to live in El Born in 2012 and while it is still beautiful with its charming streets, the problem with thiefs is HUGE. You cannot relax having a nice walk because you must watch out for little rats ready to take the knife out to rob you + they work in groups now. Now it reminds more the shadow streets of Rio de Janeiro. Horrible that the city doesnt care.
El Born (part of Barri Gòtic) is a labyrinth worth spending some time in: there are numerous restaurants and bars, quirky shops and the wonderful Picasso Museum.

We found this to be an OK place to wander in Barcelona, but didn't enjoy it as much as some other neighborhoods. Even though we used Google maps, we found it difficult to find our way to the sights we were looking for.
Amazing area. The streets are narrow plenty of alternative shops and good bars. The best street is "el passeig del born"

There are a lot of really cool neighborhoods in the city of Barcelona, but Born is outstanding. Lots of narrow streets with lots of shops, artisan and chain stores (but mostly with cool things). Bordered on one side by the Palau de la Musica, it's definitely worth spending some time there.
Here you can feel the middle age atmosphere deeply. You can be lost while walking down the narrow streets. It is one of the must see among Spain.

Well if you want to see Barcelona inside out this is one of the places to start with... it has everything but you need to spend half a day browsing and exploring the cobbled streets and enjoying the various eateries that are offering local mouthwatering food and wines. Late mornings and late evenings are the most exciting and buzzing with activity. You can easily get lost in the variety of things to do from sight seeing, shopping and eating not to forget the architecture to mesmerize you..
Bargaining is a must. One could avoid the commercial  shops here which showcase Chinese products palming them off as local manufactured products, not that there is anything wrong with them but they are run of the mill stuff... try and find your self a one of a kind gift to take back which I have no doubt you will when you walk about this lovely neighborhood. 
Have a great time
this is one of the best places to visit when you are in bcn good drinks nice buildings, just be aware of you belongings and you will have a blast

This is a nice place to kick off a tour of El Born neighborhood. It's free to walk around, and it is interesting to see the ruins that were discovered under the market. Need about an hour for it if you read all the placards that explain the site. There is a train station a couple of blocks away that had a flea market going on (Sunday) so that was a fun lil side adventure.
A lot to see and do in the neighborhood. Would have been great to have some more explanations about the place by our guide...

The apartment we stayed in was in this area so got to explore quite a bit of it. Loads of interesting bars, shops, buildings, museums and restaurants. Took a different route each time we went to and from the apartment. My wife calls it getting lost, I prefer to say we were exploring.
A good area to stay in when visiting Barcelona. Recommended by friends who originate from here and visit on a regular basis as being very civilised and the area seemed to be what I guess could be described as trendy. It is certainly well positioned to give great access on foot or by the wonderful metro system to everywhere we wanted to visit and experience.
This area has many shops that carry unique "made in Barcelona" wares.  It was recommended by a shop off the Rambla.  Don't miss the Hofmann Bakery...the BEST croissants I've ever had!
Plenty of shops for shopping, drinking coffee, admiring the architecture (some street art there), having a meal, and visiting some churches. Nice to go if you are not on a tight time frame.
Great Shops. Great Bars. Great restaurants. Winding streets that seem to go on forever! Truly a must visit area when visiting Barcelona.

We wandered around a bit and noted that this is a very cool neighborhood loaded with upscale restaurants and shopping.  Reportedly one of the areas where the hip want to live.  It's a small area and you can explore with a little time.
This was a very nice place to visit. We went through it with a tour guide.  It is not a must see, but pass through it.

Another of Barcelona’s must do areas. With the Cuitadella park on one side and Barceloneta on the other, and Basilica Santa Maria Del Mar in the middle this is an historic area worthy of some touring. I’ve been to Barcelona three times and each time I have spent time in this neighbourhood.
If you get the chance, try this for evening drinks, tapas or a meal, lovely area, clean and friendly and well worth a visit

THis is free and very intersting and well done. Shows ongoing dig & restoration of old Barcelona ruins. Well laid out and displayed with informational signs. A self walking tour. Many restaurants near by, We stayed in this neighborhood & loved the location.
Definitely make time to do the tour of El Born CCM it is only 4 EU's.  Fascinating history. We had an amazing tour guide, Sonia. You do get to walk amidst the ruins. So glad we made time to do this.

We stayed in a hotel in this area of Barcelona and really enjoyed it.  There was a large selection of bars and restaurants with some small squares secreted about in this part of older Barcelona and it was nice just walking around and feeling safe.

We stayed in El Born while in Barcelona and the neighborhood has a very young energy to it. Everywhere you go there are old buildings that now house cafes, homemade jewelry, hip bars, and takeout eateries. We never found ourselves wanting while wandering the neighborhood. Would stay again.

Had a lovely stop here with lovely drinks and great staff! So friendly and helpful, really nice food if you fancy tapas style nibbles and some well priced drinks! Really lovely, recommend! Plus a great playlist, :)
Like the Gòtic area, which is close by, it is wonderful to just walk the cobble stoned streets and people watch.  Such fun.
This is my favorite area in Barcelona together with Barceloneta. The small streets, shops, bars and everything is so nice and cool. LOVE IT!!
Interesting but would have liked more information about the ruins discovered below the market floor. I tried to download an app. as recommended but this did not work.
So many great places to visit: restaurants and bars draw the crowds, but enjoy walking the winding streets to discover new shops, talk with neighbors, and find new ways to enjoy Barcelona
Totally recommend it, go with some time to spare, and have lunch or dinner, there. There is a historical/archeological site to visit, 30 min should do.
This is a fun place.  Definitely more of a younger party type of atmosphere.  Lots of shops and bars with plenty of people watching opportunity
We stayed in this area and found it was a good spot to walk to everything. Close to some great restaurants and the waterfront.
This neighborhood is located near the Gotic and has a lot of restaurants, pubs and design stores, always open

El Born is a medieval area of the old city which has transformed itself into an area of upscale restaurants and stores. The medieval character remains as do churches and museums. The basilica I’d Santa Maria Del Mar is here as well as the Picasso museum
This area is nice as they have a free display of some Roman ruins.   Also near the gothic quarter so lots of people watching and tapas.   Subway is also close so convenient to get in and out of.
Urquinaona metro station is pickpockets heaven so be very careful with your belongings. It was very difficult to walk and enjoy being scared all the time.

This is the area that the Picasso Museum is in.  More upscale than the Bari Gothic area.  Lots of galleries, Bars, and shops.  Fun place to stroll and people watch.  We enjoyed our visit here.  It's an easy walk from the Bari Goth area or quick Metro ride.  Explore and enjoy!
We had limited time and hesitated going to the gothic quarter , but it was a wise decision to walk around . Very unique small streets , cute little local shops . You won’t regret it !

Like the Gothis quarter this are is worth a visit just to see the old areas of Barcelona.
Lots of interesting streets and places to eat

This is the new trendy part of Barcelona.
We drove through it this time but it's a good place to explore on foot

This neighborhood was a great place to stay and explore in Barcelona. Excellent location, lots to do, great restaurants and tapas bars, outdoor seating, cafes, boutiques, and close to La Barceloneta beach!

Born is the best neighborhood in Barcelona. It is authentic - lots of people actually live there - and wandering the maze of pedestrian streets you will find restaurants, coffee shops, tapas bars, boutiques and more. Charming.
The heart and soul of Barcelona.  Great shopping, food, and the Picasso museum are here.  Spend a day in this neighborhood.

I was robbed around 6:30 pm. A young Arab man approached me asking for a cigarette. Answered in English, I was not a smoker. He wanted to give me "five" and with both his hands he grabbed my watch He ran away. Hard to catch him in the very small streets between buildings. 
The night before around 11 pm we have been followed through the streets by two young men. I refused to believe and turned around a few times. Luckily we made it to the hotel door fast enough. 
Advice: stay in big groups and very populated area. But make sure your wallet is in your front pockets.

This area was one of my favorites to wander in Barcelona. So many cute little shops to find the perfect souvenir. It doesn't feel unsafe, as I read in another review, but I definitely kept my hands on my purse
If you are in to Tapas drinks and Arts , i would suggest to go to this area, a lot of good places where to eat, have a drink and you also have the Picasso museum,

Well, its the oldest by the look of it neighbourhood in old Barcelona city. Cool architecture and a heaven for Instagram posers  Went drinking and dinning a couple if times, the places we ate were quite good and the price range is mid range to expensive. But late at night, some strange fox visit this place and we do suspect illegal activities like drug selling and prostitution is a common thing there. Not advisable for a family visit with kids.

El Born is an older part of Barcelona, full of interesting old buildings. This is a great place to wander the narrow alleys, which are lined with shops and cafes, etc. This and the nearby Gothic Quarter are both great places to wander.

We had the privilege of visiting El Born via the expert guidance of the Devour Barcelona tour guide Alvaro. We learned about the incredible history of the city while sampling some of the best tapas Barcelona has to offer. If you have time, take peek at the Santa Caterina Market.
It is hard to tell the dividing line between el born and gothic quarter but great little spots to eat and shop

We spent 5 nights in Barcelona and stayed at Inside Barcelona Apartments in El Born.  The area is a fantastic place to base yourself for exploring Barcelona and despite the number of bars and restaurants, the noise was minimal and definitely not an issue when time for bed.  Also has some great unique shopping.

El Born is a must visit for anyone who graces Barcelona shores. In this zone, you'll find fashion, food and little bars that serve the best cocktails all within a stone's throw of each other. By day it is also family friendly. And as with most parts of the city, there is lots of architecture to peruse. El Born is where the trendy people who prefer a city dwelling reside, so you can be sure that you'll be in good company.
With it's narrow streets and abundance of restaurants and shops, El Born is a must visit when in Barcelona.
Unique shops with some great Tapas stops. Don't miss stopping into the Aldi's. Nothing like the one I go too.

Much nicer than anywhere on La Rambla and feels safer. We have stayed here twice, La Rambla once, Gothic quarter once and near Diagonal twice. This and Gòtic our favourite.
Full of bars, boutiques, lovely design shops, Santa Maria by the Sea, ancient ruins and funky little bars and Tapas places. Near a couple of metros and oodles of restaurants. 
Windy streets and a nice feel to it.
Has a massive Aldi supermarket nearby, Picasso Museum, foodie shops and other attractions. Close to waterfront as well.
Very nice area of Barcelona to explore.  Lots of great restaurants & wonderful people-watching.  Spend time just wondering around the streets.

An interesting area full of little lanes and passageways, very easy to get lost so you just have to take your time.  There is the Picasso museum here but it is best to book in advance.  There are loads of little boutiques all showcasing the talents of Barcelonian designers, whether it is clothing or jewellery and the prices are good.  I loved wandering around as there are lots of little tapas bars and squares as well as intriguing shops.  A very pleasant way to spend a morning or an afternoon.

very much a tourist trap so watch your pockets and don't engage with con people

interesting to see as a less obviously commercial part of Barca

Was looking forward to wandering El Born based on the reviews but to be honest we were a little disappointed.  Thought the area lacked some vibe about it and the shops/bars rather sparse.  We were in the correct area based on the maps we had but preferred the Gothic Quarter to El Born.  We visited in May so perhaps the area comes alive more later in the summer.

We never felt unsafe walking around here - exercise normal caution as you would in any large city.

In a short stay of a weekend, we witnessed two assaults. In one of them, a German lady was thrown over to the ground when they pulled her bag. 
The atmosphere in all the streets surrounding Sant Pere is really bad.

The Born area is interesting because making somehow the link between the Gothico and the area of the harbour and Barcelonetta. You can find most of the details in touristic guides, but the better is to just move around. So we found two suprising addresses: one asthonishing vine bar and shop, Magatzen Escolà, immediately behind the renovated Mercat del Born and a charming italian restaurant.: Via Margutta, carrer del Fonnolar. Astonishing interior, little terrasse outside on the plaza andd...the best white Cava sangria in whole Barcelona. Forget the Rambla.

very nice atmosphere with nice shops and restaurants.
May is still good as tourists have not yet invaded the city.
but thefts are too common and walking around with the fear of being robbed spoils the visit. the city should really loo something about it!

Very walkable so you can set your own pace and explore those aspects you enjoy the most.  Best to go off the main street to get best food and drink at good prices.  Wonderful array of shops on and next to the main drag - also lots and lots of ticky-tacky souvenir shops. Found a great sheet-music shop!
Barcelona is an amazing city filled with amazing different areas.  The Born is a must see.  Just up from harbor next to the Gothic district.  Food, shops and people watching.  Just walk and enjoy.
Don't rush through this interesting area of architecture, shops, bars, tapas. Every small street has something new to enjoy.
We visited several tapas and vermouth bars.  All were fun and good. Also lots of shopping to enjoy. Well worth the visit.

The El Born district is probably the real Barcelona that visitors should get to know. The place is a real gem. Many of the streets are narrow and crowded, but the feel is welcome and you discover new things around each corner. There are numerous cafes and restaurants to have your favourite drink or eat you favourite meal. There are also many other shops, of all types. The architecture is just amazing and it's worth visiting for this too. Many of the buildings date from the Medieval times!

We were told about El Born by the receptionist at Hilton Diagonal Mar.. 
we thoroughly enjoyed waking around in El Born, seeing the Cathedral, watching people; we ate at a very good restaurant and had some delicious tapas! 
This is just adjacent to BARRI GOTIC, the Gothic quarter in Barcelona..

Our hotel K&K Picasso was loctaed in El Born and so glad we chose this area for our trip to Barcelona. Lovely old streets and alley ways to meander , tapas bars, restaurants, bars and shops to explore. Easy walk to many other neighborhoods . Felt safe walking around late at night just treat it like any other city you travel to as far as your personal belongings are concerned. Go ! Stay !
Great neighborhood very safe,beautiful architecture small streets good food ,you can enjoy every corner bye feet ,it’s very nice to get lost a bit you can surpass yourself at each corner .
We stayed in this neighborhood for 4 nights.  It was a fabulous area to walk around and to walk into the Gothic neighborhood as well.

it is old town and a lot of small and narrow street.
a lot thing to see and interesting area.
the best area and I revisit again
Down in the Born, you are a million miles from the Ramblas (best avoided!) and can see the real Barcelona... places to wander, foods to sample – recommended.

I loved El Born and have to say it was my favourite area. Bit boho and lots of streets that don’t get to see the sun but I loved it - probably because it reminded me of Rome where I lived for many years
By far our favourite area of the city as all the bars and restaurants are good, friendly with lots of variety.

Our Apartment door was on one of the small quaint streets from the center area of El Born.  The cathedral was a 30 second walk.  the square (really a rectangle) was 30 seconds the other way.  There were a host of little restaurants and bars to visit within a minute walk from our apartment.  The Picasso Museum was a 5 minute walk.  There was a little establishment that offered a Flamingo Show for 25 Euros that lasted about 1 1/2 hrs.  There is a large building to the east that is called the El Born, it host a variety of events.  On the other side is a seafood restaurant that our hotel recommend that was suburb.  You can find it by the lines that were waiting outside.  Well worth the 10 -15minute wait.  The El Franco train terminal was 5 minutes away to the southwest so the area is easy to get to.  When we return to Barcelona we will once again stay in this area

El Born was a great area to stay in.  The small, winding alleys were part of a web that connected to the Gotic area.  There were great places to eat, drink wine or visit.  The Picasso Museum was there and the area had great little shops. Our flat had the windows that opened up with room for a cafe table & chairs and we'd have coffee or vermut while watching pedestrians walk thru the maze of alleys below us. I'd return in a beat.

The Picasso Museum, the Basilica de Santa Maria del Mar and the amazing Air BnB Flamenco show are here (see other review).  Easy to get around. But this is probably the second most 'touristy' spot that we visited.  When you see the daily special in English and not Catalan - you know your in tourist town.

If you wander out one side of the neighborhood you'll find Parc de la Ciutadella.  Cool park that has the Arco de Triunfo de Barcelona on one end.  Worth a visit if your feet can take the extra walking.

The Picasso Museum, the Basilica de Santa Maria del Mar, a huge beautiful park, and many hidden gems -- some of which we found thanks to our fabulous "Devour Barcelona" guide, Norah Piniera (try to arrange a walking tour with her!) and some of which we found on our own.  Don't forget to visit the Mercat de Santa Caterina where you can purchase an entire meal for next to nothing (I started the day with a delicious croissant from "La Torna", just inside the main entrance.  And as you exit, check out the Roman ruins that were uncovered during the building of the market.
We walked through this cozy area. It was packed with people, but worthwhile a visit. Many restaurants, bars and shops are located here
My hotel was in this area and I thought it was perfect.  Close access to the beach and adjacent to the Barrio Gothic neighborhood.

Spent a very enjoyable couple of hours on a twilight stroll through this area.  Lots of great shops selling local goods, cool little bars and places to eat mixed with galleries and museums. A great contrast to the high end fancy facaded retail on the nearby Passeig de Gracia.

Highly recommend walking in El Born, there are many nice cafes,
also Picasso Museum and Dalmases Palace.

We were able to secure the coolest Airbnb just steps from La Rambla and it was so much fun exploring the gothic quarter both day and night! No shortage of shops or restaurants in any direction. Tapas hopping and the Mercat boqueria were my favorite parts Of Barcelona and Spain!
From the arc to those lovely blue lamp posts, El Born was my favorite part of Barcelona to get lost in.
So many interesting areas to explore away from the "tourist" traps just wander the alleyways and admire this wonderful city.
Fine venue next to Santa Maria del Mar churchyard. Talas bars, restaurants and some nice shops around, you will hav efaun day and night.
Your visit to Barcelona is not complete until you've visited the beautiful neighborhood of El Born. The narrow little streets, so many artisan shops, restaurants and shops. It's magical!
Here my favourite quarter in Barcelona! Great atmosphere, reasonable prices and some kind of bohemian energy on the air. El Born is one of those places that never stops and I love that!
very lively area lots of places to see, shop, eat and just people watch. Recommend for any Barcelona visitor

EL bonn is  a great place to eat and drink,lots of hidden bars and restaurants which are visited by the locals , as its very hard to find them unless you have prior information. Lively nightlife, not expensive at all and the food is great.
One of my favourite places on Earth - you do feel like in one of the Zafon's novels. Hope to retire in Spain and be able to wonder at El Born regularly!

If you like your architecture and historical buildings, the El Born district is the place to go. In my view this is the real Barcelona with its own Basillica, the Picasso museum and the Barcelona Cathedral nearby

We spent our entire time in Barcelona walking, exploring, wandering, and eating and drinking when we felt like it. El Born area is very nice and artsy and feels a bit younger. We spent some time walking around here for sure.
We stayed in this area during our honeymoon. Plenty of shops and resturants and we felt safe wandering around exploring at night. Centrally located so we could walk or take subway everywhere.
if you like gothic arcitecture you should see this spot of barcelona its mainly the best part of the town
This was such an interesting place to visit and throughly recommend it to anyway interested in history

We really enjoyed walking around the El Born district on our food tour with Wanderbeak (they were amazing).  In fact, this little area was one of our favorites for its maze like corridors and lovely little shops and bakeries.

Lots of things to do around here. Ciutadella park, picasso museum, good food, nice market, nice paseo. Good for a drink, for a walk for shopping. 
We love it.
Whether for food and drink, or for losing oneself in the maze of alleys, to find a small hidden sqaure - a great quarter to visit.

This district of Barcelona is an outstanding for site seeing.  There are hidden plaza's and lane ways everywhere you go and it is a pleasure when you get lost as there is a lot to see. Is also blends into the Gothic quarter seamlessly without out you knowing.  Super area to visit and explore.

We went exploring the El Born area in the evening and the best way to discover it is by getting lost. Which is what happened us.
Loads of side streets.

The Born neighborhood is where you will find the Santa Caterina Market, the Basilica de Santa Maria del Mar, and the Picasso Museum.  You can reach it on the Yellow Metro Line at Jaume.  
A lot of artistic type shop and a good block or two with Picasso themed merchandise. Most of the streets are even narrower than in the Gothic section, but there are just as many restaurants and shops.  There seemed to be more young people living here than in other areas that I saw. 
Over all, just as nice as the Gothic section.

This was my second visit to Barcelona and first time staying in the El Born area.
So glad we did. It is a gritty, fascinating maze of narrow alleys that open onto bright squares full of restaurants, shops, bars and life! The Picasso Museum was quite close and provided yet another layer of culture. If/when I return to Barcelona, I know exactly where I will be staying again.

We stayed at the Barcelona Edition hotel in the Born area for 3 days and really enjoyed this area vs. our first few days in the busier La Ramblas area.  We loved getting lost in all the little streets in this area and stopping at several of the shops and small coffee shops/restaurants for drinks.  I would recommend staying in this area if you don't want the busy La Ramblas area which is only a short walk away.

I am so glad that I didn't pass up the opportunity to visit this historic part of the city, where some of the cities oldes buildings reside.

The Born district isn't large, but it's easy to get lost because of the way the streets are constructed. They are all over the place, almost as if the blue print for their design was a pretzel. Some people might find that annoying, but in actuality it's the opposite. It's a lot of fun. Interesting shops, restaurants and boutiques pop up from all kinds of unlikely places as you meander around.

From the standpoint of photography, the district is very challenging because of the high contrast. Because the buildings are tall and close together and the streets are so narrow, a lot of the space is in shade. If part of the sky is included in a shot, the sky will be blown out, or the shadows will be too underexposed. Either way, not good. My workaround was to just shoot one or the other, or keep the sky as minimized as possible. Next time, I need to bring a graduated, ND filter. But if you are a phone photographer, I wouldn't worry about it. ( :

If you are a fan of distinctive architecture, like to people watch, like to explore quirky, interesting shops and boutiques, and sample different kinds of foods without walking all over the city, definitely check out the Born District. You'll be glad you did.

The El  Born district of Barcelona features some of the oldest buildings in the city. It features very  narrow passage way streets lending an aura of mystery to the place.  There are numerous restaurants in the Born. Now while this district is interesting it does not hold a candle to the Passeig de Gracia street/area which is lined with some of the most elegant buildings in Europe. The Casa Batllo home designed by Gaudi is but one example.

El Born is a historical neighborhood located in between the Gothic Quarter and Ciutadella Park. El Born is one of Barcelona's most popular neighborhoods. Home to some of the oldest buildings in Barcelona and intertwined with amazing streets and passage ways. Home to amazing culture, bars, shops and restaurants. Jolly Chriss.
We visited here with Catalan friends.  It showed some of the excavations of early Barcelona and the marketplace it used to be. The area around El Born is also quite interesting.  It is worth a visit.
We stayed in an apartment in the Born area and enjoyed the access to restaurants and some of the activities.
Fabulous, vibrant area of Barcelona not to be missed. We spent a day just wandering the streets of Born and stopping off for an occasional coffee and pastry!

We stayed at Hotel Picasso in El Born -- so well located -- walk to many restaurants and all were excellent!  walking through El Born was a treat -- and it was so convenient to all the old city has to offer.  Great location.
Terrific area of Barcelona. We came down a couple of times during our time there and we shopped and we had dinner.
MUST VISIT WHILST IN BARCELONA!  If you are into local boutique / artie stuff then this is your place.   Just off Las Ramblas.

The El Born neighbourhood is one of the very best neighbourhoods in Barcelona and is steeped in history. 
Once the stomping ground of the aristocracy and central in the rich trading tradition of Barceloneta due to its close proximity to the sea,it's a wonderful area to stay or just to visit.
The architecture in this neighbourhood is outstanding, Medieval, Gothic and Roman,you'll find it all here,visit the wonderful Plaça De Sant Pere,marvel at the Sant Pere Romanesque Church and enjoy a cooling drink or head to the beautiful Palau De La Musica Catalana, a great piece of architecture, some of the best traditional bodegas are to be found here,walk in the footsteps of Picasso who arrived in El Born at the age of 15,if you enjoy your retail therapy there's an amazing amount of shopping outlets here,it's just one outstandingly beautiful area to visit. 
Most definitely well worth checking out if your planning a holiday to this most vibrant of cities.
This is my favorite part of the city. There's so much amazing shopping and food. If you can only go to one part of Barcelona, this would be my pick.

literally across the street from the gothic quarter El Born was a great surprise. our air bnb was on a. vibrant street with small markets, fresh juice shops, cafes, tapas restaurants, walking distance to gothic quarter, we walked to the beach every day. I think the more low-key trendy spots are in El born because rent is less $$ vs Gothic Quarter. We even got caught up in a national holiday and a great parade ensued.

We normally avoid the super touristy sections of cities; we were pleasantly surprised by El Born's history and the great mix of stores and amenities it had. This is one touristy neighborhood that's worth visiting.

Lovely narrow cobbled streets, local shops selling craft items. Some great bars and restaurants tucked away in every direction. Lots of squares and areas to sit out and people watch. Less commercialised and tacky than other areas.

The only negative is some of the bars in the main areas don't allow you to sit outside and just order drinks, you have to order food too, which can be a bit annoying but understand why.
Not as many artisans as I had expected.  Few authentic restaurants offering authentic Catalonia menu.  Quiet/

Love love love this area of Barcelona. Really good for exclusive shops and if you want to buy something different. Amazing churches and architecture. Lots of cobbled streets that wind in and out. A medieval tour is highly recommended to get the history and a  better feel for the area.
We have enjoyed nice lunch in this place .You can choose any kinds of food.You need to walk around to see the beauty of this place

In my 8 days in Barcelona, I walked around El Born twice and Gotic Barri twice. I prefer El Born more. Alleys are more narrow. Restaurant scene from 5pm to 10pm is more vibrant. It is a hopping place.
Great for viewing. The kids loved it. Awesome experience and a peak in the past for everyone. Loved it
Wander around and enjoy the amazing shops, eateries, and history. Right next door to the Gothic. What are you waiting for?

You can't really review this area as it is so diverse.  Full of small streets, alleyways, shops, restaurants, museums, boutique hotels, pickpockets and also many parades/performers in peak season.  Take your time and soak up the atmosphere.  Stop off for wine and tapas but remember that you will be paying tourist prices especially in the shops.  The area does merge imperceptibly into poorer quarters so be aware of this although I have never felt unsafe there.
Lots of lovely tapas bars and restaurants. Spent most night around here and had to book from some rrestaurants
The area has character and a great vibe. Our hotel was located here and if we went back to Barcelona, we'd stay in the same area. Great tapas, little boutiques and great coffee at El Magnifico.

El Born is a great neighborhood centrally located to nearly everything in the old city. Most visitor attractions are at maximum a 10-15 minute walk away - plus - walking through El Born is bonus in itself given the shops, the wonderful restaurants and the narrow and twisting streets. We got a chance to stay in the neighborhood for 5 nights and it was well worth it. Very enjoyable area.

Just watch out for the motor bikes, cars, scooters, trucks, skate boards, etc that seemingly share the walk streets with us pedestrians! Took a little getting use to but it was fun in the end!
We spent most of our time in Barcelona in the Born district.  Many museums, restaurants , interesting bars and great people and shops.
we went there for a night walk ... really amazing place different than the regulars areas in Barcelona it has her own charm and unique  ....go have drink at night and discover the beauty of the place

We based ourselves in El Born to really get a feel for what we felt was the heart and pulse of Barcelona. We were not disappointed. El Born is in close proximity to the Gothic Quarter and we spent our days exploring the laneways and discovering amazing architecture, food, culture, shopping and really enjoyed the vibe.

This is a fun part of the city to explore for a sense of the old town and to find truly unique shopping where you may well be talking directly to the designer/artist while you are in the shop.  There is great food in this district.  As in any large city, this is a place to be vigilant, as pickpocketing can happen.

lovely part of the city, we walked through narrow streets lined with interesting shops, not least of which was the little cake shop with the yummy looking breads, traditional Turron and the brightly coloured sugar rocks! Well worth a visit!
Definitely my favorite area in Barcelona.  The cooking class was there as well...Born to Cook!   Ari was amazing.  Paella and a bunch of other stuff.  A wonderful day!!
This was our favorite area in all of Barcelona!  Great shopping, strolling and not to crowed!  Highly Rec over other areas!

When visiting Barcelona, the heart of the historic city are the Gothic Quarter, La Ribera/El Born and the Eixample. They are in close proximity to each other and are all wonderful to explore. Like the Gothic Quarter, El Born (also known as La Ribera) resides in the Ciutat Vella district and El Born simply felt like an extension of the Gothic Quarter.  It is a magical area with much to see and a charming mish mash streets to wander.  

Most prominently, El Born is home to the Picasso Museum. Some of the other major attractions that we really enjoyed include Basilica de Santa Maria del Mar (a magnificent church which offers free admission before 13:00), the moderniste Palace of Catalan Music, and the archeological dig at El Born Cultural and Memorial Center. Plus, just wandering and exploring the narrow, colorful streets is a joy.
Love the uniqueness of this neighborhood. Artsy shops and cafes. Take time to get lost and wonder the winding streets.

El Born is a part of the old center between Barri Gotic and Parc Ciutadella.
It is wonderful to walk in the small and narrow streets between beautiful buildings.
The most famous attractions in El Born is Basilica de Santa Maria del Mar and Museu Picasso.
This is one of my favorite places to hang..hipster area..many young  people are here.. good food too..
A great old section full of pedestrian streets and alleys, small shops, and people from here, there and everywhere enjoying the good life.

It is a really lovely area in Barcellona.
Full of life, fun, restaurants and bars..surrounded by an incredible artistic and cultural atmosphere !!
Barcelona style..which I found extremely amazing!!

Spent two nights at a hotel in El Born neighborhood.  It’s located adjacent to the Gothic Quarter and about a 10-minute walk to La Rambla.  The Jaume I Metro stop is perfect for connecting to other parts of the city.

My husband and I went through this district with our Tapas tour guide, whom we ran into on the street one night. As she took us through this neighborhood, you find all kinds of small squares full of tables with people enjoying food and drink, laughing and just enjoying some leisurely time with friends and family. Stroll through this place is you can, you may just find a quaint little plaza to stop and have  nice beer or sangria.
See the Picasso Museum and Church of Santa Maria del Mar.  Enjoy a sidewalk cafe.  Wander through the narrow streets.

I love wandering around this area. Many of the stores are owned by independents who make their own products. The store owners are the friendliest in all of Barcelona and I have learned many wonderful things from my "local" friends. For example: Any restaurant in Barcelona has to let you use the restroom, even if you don't purchase anything!!

We lived at El Born during out Barcelona Visit. El Born is a beautiful place with nice cafes, nice bars, great food. 

It's also a centre point to go to the fanous attraction of Barcelona. 

EL Born はバルセロナの中心にある町です。
いいカフェ、美味しいご飯はたくさんあります。
バルセロナの有名な所からも近いですね。

The area is lively but not ridiculous - happening but bubbling colourful but not too vibrant.So many shops restaurants cafes back cracks tiny streets all brilliant to walk around. A bustling area that is a joy to spend time in
I love walking around the area of the Born when I visit Barcelona. It's uber cool, and has both quirkyand alternative, and elegant restaurants and bars.

I stayed in the El Born district which is in the heart of the Gothic area. The architecture, shopping -both brand and unique boutique stores were plenty. You can walk for miles exploring and not even leave the area!

During our visit in Barcelona, we walked through El Born and enjoyed the beauty of the area.   We found El Born to have the best places to eat.   Loved our Barcelona experience!  Would go back again and see more.

A lovely area which is much less crowded than the Ramblas/ Gothic areas, full of lovely boutiques, bars and restaurants. Also has cute playgrounds for the kids if they are traveling with you.
Highly recommended if you want to get away from the crowds
Cool area with lots of unique shops.  Old world streets with boutique shops and lots of Tapas.  Enjoyed our time there.

Im sure you can go here when your older but I would think that maybe when you are 40 you don't want a bar hop as much as you did in your 20s. The general crowd here I would say ranges from 25-35. The bars are all great and three always something to do day and night in El Born
Small windy streets filled with boutiques around each turn. One of a kind objects, great art, and great food.

El Born has experienced an amazing re-birth.  Go and get lost in the alley and passageways that criss-cross this area.  Stop at a cafe, drop into a shop, and otherwise enjoy the coolest part of Barcelona.
This is like Barcelona used to be. Good food, not overcrowded and with a wonderful ambiance. Will always stay here in the future.
Loved El Born.  Beautiful quaint neighborhood with great bars and restaurants. Also a great place to do shopping in small boutiques.
So fun here! It is filled with little shops and amazing restaurants. I was able to buy handmade pottery in a little shop. This district is home to the Picasso Museum and other art shops.
We loved walking through this area it is easily the nicest and most historic part of town. Great food and interesting cafes and restaurants. Great place to get lost in the streets also less crowded.
With all the small boutiques and food optins, if you are into wandering adn getting lost, this is a great area.
my favourite part of Barcelona  - most interesting shops & restaurants. and a little less crowded than other areas of the city.

We loved walking through all the streets and shopping areas. Great food and great hidden gems tucked away. We got lost in the streets and found great cocktail bars, restaurants and a Flamenco show. Make sure you stop by here for a couple hours!

Due to the proximity of the Picasso Museum, El Born is lively day and night. Little treasures are in the alley ways such as a quaint neighborhood bar, tapas joint, or apothecary. Little tchotchkes can be found fir friends at home for just a few euro. Don’t miss Tompero Tapas Bar! A must!

Enjoy a short visit to this historic neighborhood full of narrow streets among some wide boulevards. There are many local restaurants and bars to enjoy. However the area has the international chains mixed among tourist shops and some artisan shops.

i was reading a few recent reviews of el born and came across someone who described this area as a tourist trap, suggesting that barcelona had so much more to offer.

dumbfounded. all i can think is this person must have their parts of the city confused.  el born a tourist trap? couldn't be further than the truth.  passeig de gracia is a tourist trap. la rambla is a tourist trap.

el born is one of the oldest areas of barcelona and like the gothic quarter is a maze of narrow winding streets designed for walking and exploring. you'll discover some amazing restaurants here like Pla De La Garsa, Bar del Pla and Tapeo Born.  there's the picasso museum and the basilica de santa maria del mar, a stunning basilica dating back to the 1300's.

We ate mostly every meal in El Born as it was closest to where we were staying. Many great restaurants, but avoid the restaurants with terraces in the plaza - many are tourist traps and also charge a 10% surcharge for sitting outside. Great neighborhood to wander through.

The last day of our multi country trip to Europe, our party of 4 looked forward to spending time in El Born. We've all been to Barcelona several times and were excited to look at the handmade craft stores and eat at some great tapas bars and restaurants, and generally feeling the vibe of the Gothic area and El Born.  This is a warning to be careful, as I was very careful and had very little on me when I was pickpocketed.  I'm pretty sure the street we were on was Carrer de la Boria, which was filled with interesting graffiti and small interesting stores and local bars and markets. We stopped at a gelato place, mostly open to the street about midway on the street.  The young girl at the counter took my money on the highest counter which made me reach up and made it difficult to keep my small cross body bag under my arm as I was carrying it through the day.  In retrospect, she also did some dropping and shuffling with the money which kept my hands up high (one hand with gelato, the other trying to get the change).  I noticed the phone gone from my purse within a block later.  Many of the salespeople there said the pickpockets work in packs, and sometimes are part of the restaurant where this happens.  Although we were not in a restaurant, I wish I had reported it to the police so they could have checked this out, but it's very hard while lacking time and traveling in another country.  I felt lucky that it was just my phone, although a 3 month old Iphone X, still felt lucky.  Be extra careful!  I'm a seasoned aware traveler and don't think there was much I could have done differently, so don't take passports and much cash, whatever you do.  I still love being in Barcelona, it will not stop me from returning.
Walk through is fine. Try not to eat or shop as this is another tourist trap. Barcelona has so much more to offer   Do a little research and you will find true artisans in this city.

We spend a lovely afternoon in Born, shopping for beautiful handmade fashion, jewellery and ceramics, then a delicious tapas lunch at Bar del Pla. A great place to visit, definitely underated on the tourist circuit!

Great little area of eating, shopping and more eating.
The sounds of church bells ring out from Basilica de Santa Maria
Nice area of older Barcelona. The narrow streets, small shops and restaurants remind us a bit of Venice. Good area to wander around and perhaps get lost like we did!
this neighborhood has a very positive vibe I just love it with all it's beautiful buildings and rich architecture

We were delighted to discover the el Born former market, now center for culture and memory. The excavations of a neighborhood discovered beneath the venue were fascinating and well-documented with timelines of what was happening during the active life of the area. One not to miss.

This medieval neighborhood is perhaps the most interesting in all of Barcelona! The streets are named after the trades that worked in them several hundred years ago. Today, the twisty narrow little labyrinth of streets contain a cornucopia of unique shops and some of the best tapas restaurants in the city!

This is a great place to wander and get lost in! You will find something interesting around every corner!

This is one of the better places to see old Barcelona with its narrow dark streets, interesting architecture and small and interesting shops and restaurants. Allow a few hours to stroll around and take in the sights.

We had a bucket list of 20 places to visit in Barcelona during our stay, we managed 3 This was largely due to spending time in areas like Eixample, Gracia, Montjuic and here. You see an interesting building or monument and before you know it you are exploring the area. We read that in medieval times this area was the playground and private domain of the aristocracy. There is an array of small galleries, small museums, artisan shops, variety shops, and the Museu Picasso. Enjoy the shady streets, the small parks, the sculptures or just sit and enjoy a coffee and then walk on to the Parc de la Ciutadella.

El Bourne was our favourite neighbourhood of Barcelona! With all the charm of the Gothic Quarter but away from the masses of tourists! So much choice of restaurants and places to sit and have a quick drink! Lovely!

We loved strolling in El Born and did so before and after visiting the Picasso Museum in El Born.  There are so many little streets and alleys to become lost in and so many great restaurants.  We want to return to Barcelona and when we do, we'll definately plan more time to explore El Born.
Fun district to visit and walk around. Lots of interesting shops and restaurants. Just of  Las Rambla

Next to the Gottic quarter, this is also an old part of Barcelona. There is a culture center with archeologic buildings from the 17th century. It is nice to walk in the allies and soak in the atmosphere. The Picasso Museum is located here, if you love art.

in this area you can find a lot of modern and original restaurant, there are a lot of mexican food, with mexican people, very good nachos, at night there are a lot of people drinking in the street and good vibes

We spent a morning wandering around this area and we were really empressed their was a lovely church to visit. The area is very arty and has some lovely shops and resturants and from here you can walk onto the gothic quarter and the rambles. We would of liked to go back here on an evening as it had so many resturants and bars. We preferred the streets and shops here rather than the rambles.

We were staying nearby and nearly everywhere we went started out the El Born-- what a treat!  There are myriad narrow streets to wander, SO many food options from tapas to lunch to evening restaurants and lots of public seating areas that seem to magically open up before you just when you thought you were in a never-ending alley.  We were here morning, afternoon, evening and night at it was always bustling with wonderful energy.
This is one of those "Must Dos" in Barcelona.  It is a unique and wonderful place with many places to explore.
Like the Gothic Quarter, this neighborhood is also a lovely area to explore. Lots of shops, bars and restaurants. Very touristy and can be pricier than other areas.

Little streets, lights over your head, funky shops and craft boutiques – soak into the atmosphere and get the vibe. Bastaix wine and tapas place is really good, to be found right next to the Basilica Santa Maria del Mar.
Right near the Gothic quarter. Similar in feel. Wander...get lost in the maze of streets. Just the right size to explore. Great little shops.

We enjoyed this district particularly around the St Maria del Mar.  It has shop that are a bit different---offering items more unique to the other districts....maybe b/c it is near the Picasso Museum.  We enjoyed drinks and food in the plaza in from the Maria del Mar with local musicians strolling around and the view of the church in front of us.
Loads of history can be found here. I did a walking tour of this area and it was so informative. It was great to see a different side of Barcelona.
El Born is located in the center of Barcelona. It is a great neighborhoods for shopping, eating, and drinking. There is always something going on.

We stayed in El Born during our most recent trip, and loved it. It's close to many bars and restaurants, and while it's getting more touristy, we still found it full of residents with a great local vibe. It's walking distance to most major sights, and centrally located to take public transit to to those that are further away. We would definitely consider staying here again on a return trip.

This area suits everyone. Great shopping. Little independent shops.Great little cafes and restaurants. Great sight seeing. I loved exploring the narrow streets and finding something new. This is definitely the best part of Barcelona. We spent the whole day and evening there.
History of Barca is explained, do visit if time permits. Take the audio tour. Would take 2 hours to complete all.

If you enjoy unique shops and authentic restaurants this is the place for you!  Lots of winding streets lead you to one store after another - all with beautiful, some locally made, products - expensive but you won't find these pieces anywhere else!  This is not a hot spot for your average tourist - you'll find locals as well as visitors but the environment is low key and special.
Charming neighborhood. We could have gone back to visit several times if we would have been in Barcelona longer. Bring your wallet - lots of great shops!
